11588: Cloud of Faeries.author: mtear
11588: Cloud of Faeries.text_parsed:
Best card ever.

Turn 1: Island.
Turn 2: Island. Tap one island for High Tide. Play Cloud of Faeries, untap your two lands. Tap them for four mana. Play Helm of Awakening for 2. Play Snap for 1, targeting Faeries. Untap your lands and tap them for 5 floating mana. Play Faeries for 1, untapping lands and tapping for 8 floating mana total in mana pool.

THEN:
Future Sight
Sensei's Divining Tops
= Draw your whole deck and get a very large storm count, or infinite mana through use of the cards in it. Then brainfreeze or braingeyser.

OR:
Cowardice
Lightning Greaves
=Infinite storm count and infinite mana

OR:
Cloudstone Curio
Another Cloud of Faeries (or just any other cheap creature)
= Infinite storm count and infinite mana

OR:
Equilibrium
Another Cloud of Faeries (or just any other cheap creature)
= Infinite storm count and infinite mana

So many other ways for a second turn kill, so little time.

11588: Cloud of Faeries.author: blurrymadness
11588: Cloud of Faeries.text_parsed:
The better you get, the better this card gets. Forget combos; consider equips and tempo. Playing this gives you a 1/1 flyer with counterspell mana open. If you can keep your counter-mana open all game while laying/responding to threats, there is just about nothing an opponent can do.

Hidden strings works well with it as well, for the same reason; add in the evasion to make it so that by T3, not a turn goes by with closed counter-mana.

12349: Delusions of Mediocrity.author: Mode
12349: Delusions of Mediocrity.text_parsed:
It's a nice remake of Delusions of Grandeur with half the life points used, but without any upkeep cost.

This makes it far less useful for a Donate combo, but it still has decent uses with cards that interact with lifeloss and lifegain: The aforementioned Sanguine Bond or Ageless Entity for instance; or Children of Korlis/Tainted Sigil to offset the drawback (or even gain a load of life again when saccing two).
When playing against mono red or black decks (or those without enchantment removal in general) this also makes some cheap life gain, which certainly isn't a common thing for blue.
12349: Delusions of Mediocrity.text_posted:
It's a nice remake of [autocard]Delusions of Grandeur[/autocard] with half the life points used, but without any upkeep cost.

This makes it far less useful for a [autocard]Donate[/autocard] combo, but it still has decent uses with cards that interact with lifeloss and lifegain: The aforementioned [autocard]Sanguine Bond[/autocard] or  [autocard]Ageless Entity[/autocard] for instance; or [autocard]Children of Korlis[/autocard]/[autocard]Tainted Sigil[/autocard] to offset the drawback (or even gain a load of life again when saccing two).
When playing against mono red or black decks (or those without enchantment removal in general) this also makes some cheap life gain, which certainly isn't a common thing for blue.

12349: Delusions of Mediocrity.author: Equinox523
12349: Delusions of Mediocrity.text_parsed: The thing that made Illusions of Grandeur broken in the eyes of many was how deadly the cumulative upkeep made it when Donated. Here, the lifegain it halved and its usefulness for this application is also dampened. However, it's still worth noting that 10 life is nothing to scoff at, especially when running Phyrexian mana for things like Immolating Souleater. It also gets you well along your way for Test of Endurance.

Many hours by moonlit night
Did I strive to set my selection aright

A deck that would bring renown
Thus, all my labors wouldst it crown

A legion, lined up to the sea
Must the number of my win conditions be

Fine as crystal, my mana curve

At last my opponent, hours, days recouped
Four Titans and a Jace? F*ck you, I scoop

12355: Tragic Poet.author: Mode
12355: Tragic Poet.text_parsed:
I wondered if this might have any use with Standstill, but it won't work out:

If you cast Standstill immediately after her, she's pseudo-protected from spells if you opponent does not want Standstill to trigger. But he very likely does want it in this case, since he better destroys her immediately and grants you the card advantage from Standstil immediately instead of delaying his problem and ending up with you saccing her and recasting Standstill.

On the other hand, forcing your opponent to respond to a 1cc card doesn't seem that bad. But it's easily pinged away with various abilities as well, so this won't net you any advantage afterall i'm afraid...
12355: Tragic Poet.text_posted:

12355: Tragic Poet.author: chaos_noise
12355: Tragic Poet.text_parsed:
I met a traveller from an antique land
Who said: `Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed.
And on the pedestal these words appear --
"My name is Urza, king of kings:
Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!"
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.'

12356: Expendable Troops.author: TreeTrunkMaster
12356: Expendable Troops.text_parsed:
Almost like white direct damage, but slow since you have to tap to use it.
Not saying it's great, but it makes your opponent have to think a little harder about whether they want to attack or block with certain creatures, or they make a mistake and you get rid of something your normally couldn't have.
Removal spells are more effective, things like this give opponents more to think about and increase the chances they will make a mistake (related to this effect or not).
3.5/5

12359: Cessation.author: sweetgab
12359: Cessation.text_parsed:
This would have been slightly overpowered today, since turn three Cessation into turn four Supreme Verdict is a lot of value. This is why the bounce cost on Agoraphobia is quite high, at 2U, and why Martial Law has to cost four. Similar effects costed at three (Scepter of Dominance) have definitely seen play, and even that thing had a one mana activation cost.

If you know anything about Urza's block though, it is very clear that this card had absolutely no chance of seeing play back then.

12360: Radiant's Judgment.author: nemokara
12360: Radiant's Judgment.text_parsed:
"That guy in the art doesn't look like he has power 4 or greater."

Actually, it's not uncommon for a creature card with high power/toughness to represent a group of creatures that typically have a low P/T. Some examples are Mass of Ghouls/Rotting Legion (zombies), Naya Sojourners/Ezuri's Brigade (elves), Scuzzback Marauders/Boggart Mob (goblins), Thraben Militia/Vindictive Mob (humans), and Jackalope Herd (bunnies).

12372: Bouncing Beebles.author: jfre81
12372: Bouncing Beebles.text_parsed:
Bouncing Beebles likes the Mirrodin blocks quite a bit, in general. At worst he's solid blue creature sideboard. Who doesn't like an unblockable 2/2 for 3 CMC?

In head-to-head, get Leyline of Sanctity and Jinxed Idol on the board, sack a creature to hand them the Idol for good, and have that hit and the Beebles hit for a combined four that can't be stopped without some removal. Oh, they don't have a way to burn off the Beebles or destroy the Idol? That's too bad. The Leyline makes sure they're stuck with the Idol, and removes forced sacrifice a la Geth's Verdict as an option to get rid of the Beebles. Throw a Diplomatic Immunity on them and it's even harder to break. Keep a counter handy for any Wrath of God type blanket removal.

Have answers for their answers and a simple combo can go a long way.
12372: Bouncing Beebles.text_posted:

12374: Snap.author: Azr43l
12374: Snap.text_parsed: I'd say this is better than unsummon. You can't do it your first turn, bt why would you unsummon on your first turn anyway? After that, it can pretty much be free.
12374: Snap.text_posted: I'd say this is better than unsummon. You can't do it your first turn, bt why would you unsummon on your first turn anyway? After that, it can pretty much be free.

12374: Snap.author: Mode
12374: Snap.text_parsed:
Oh Snap!
I love that card. Then again, who does not love bouncing for free (regarding mana of course, not card advantage), and possibly even generating an additional mana or two?
In some cases even worth using on your own creatures to trigger certain cip/etb effects once more, as with Cloud Faeries if you have a land which produces more than one mana when tapped, or to rescue one of your creatures which is being targeted by removal.
And i also think it's better than Unsummon in general - nobody urgently wants to bounce a creature in the first turn anyways (except for threats like a Goblin Lackey), and not being able to cast Snap when drawing it since you've only one open mana left won't happen that often either.

Oh, and you know this won't work nammertime since Isochron Scepter won't untap from untapping lands, right?^^
12374: Snap.text_posted:

And i also think it's better than [autocard]Unsummon[/autocard] in general - nobody urgently wants to bounce a creature in the first turn anyways (except for threats like a [autocard]Goblin Lackey[/autocard]), and not being able to cast Snap when drawing it since you've only one open mana left won't happen that often either.

12381: Raven Familiar.author: Mode
12381: Raven Familiar.text_parsed:
Ah yes, Raven Familiar. Probably best known for its use in conjuction with Cavern Harpy (or Man-o'-War) in Aluren decks for mana-free card advantage. Drawing cards for 1 life each hadn't been so much fun since Necropotence ;)

That might be a really dumb story, but i once thought you would bounce cards with echo rather than sacrificing them.
You can imagine how much i loved playing this card with that deception :P
(It's just that loveable in an Aluren deck though ;) )

Now if someday there should in fact be a permanent that lets you bounce cards with echo rather than saccing them, i know what card i will put into a deck with that :D
(Seeing how most cards with echo come with a nice cip/etb trigger, this would actually be a card i'd look forward to.
Or as Smojed_Peasant suggested, a card that makes the abilities trigger again when the cards are put into a graveyard would be comparably interesting.)

And that's some cool artwork - i like the academy laboratory atmosphere, and notice how there seems to be an interchange of thoughts between the wizard and the raven.

Oh, and if you're also running white i'd likely play Court Hussar instead ;)

@kdraphael (3 years late): the first set with Echo always had it constant - you pay its casting cost again. It says so in the reminder text (pay its casting cost instead of its echo cost). Later sets separated the echo cost from the casting cost, and wrote the echo cost as part of the ability.

12382: King Crab.author: GradiustheFox
12382: King Crab.text_parsed:
Ah, nothing like a bit of dissonance between text and art. Heavy attack power and effectively an instant kill capability, but in the art it's clutching a lizard among some assumedly normal sized beach pebbles. Unless this Olivia person is a lizard...
Anyway! Sure the effect is a little niche and the startup cost is a little high, but yikes. If you do hit a Green user you can lock them down from getting any fresh cards. And because of the 'unique' wording of the effect, it gets around Indestructibility and other such factors that would normally make something hard to kill, so it gets rid of stuff without fail. One fifth of the time, that is.

12383: Tinker.author: ChaosFire
12383: Tinker.text_parsed:
@VampireCat:

Ok...Tinker is only legal in Vintage. You're not going to play artifact lands in Vintage, they're worse than basic lands for Vintage's purposes. Secondly, why even bother with the artifact lands, you have a sol ring and a mox out.

As for everyone else...

GET OFF THE BLIGHTSTEEL HORSE. It's just a creature. You know what wins the turn it comes out? Time Vault. None of this waiting-a-turn crap. And that's important. Because unless something's gone horribly, horribly wrong, Vintage games don't go longer than MAYBE your turn 2, usually not even that long.

Here: Mox Saphire, Mana Vault, Tolarian Academy, play Tinker sacking Mana Vault putting Time Vault into play tapped, play Voltaic Key with one of your floating mana and use the other to activate the kay and untap the Time Vault. Use Time Vault and take infinite turns until you've played enough lands and Voltaic Keys to win with a Phyrexian Collossus. Or your beloved Blightsteel Collossus.

Oh, and my de***ion up there left you with 2 cards still in hand, aka Force of Will and something blue.

I love Vintage.

EDIT: Apparently S C R I P T is in the censor somehow...

12383: Tinker.author: DarthParallax
12383: Tinker.text_parsed:
Tinker is the Grandsire of a large percentage of archetypes in Vintage.

Time Vault is also such a card.

And Tendrils of Agony.

The thing is, no Time Vault deck would be caught dead without Tinker, probably few to zero Tendrils cards would be caught dead without Time Vault.

Many many cards are broken in Old School Magic, and many of them lead to dominatingly powerful decks.

Tinker just might be one of the EASIEST to see exactly what you do with it and make decks that do stupid things, though. I mean you don't have to own or have played against Moxen to know that your Ornithopter is one of the best cards in your deck when you look at Tinker.

Wizards tries to avoid printing undercosted cards because they lead to fast ways to win. But they LOVE making ALL KINDS of over-costed shite, especially in Artifacts. Tinker cheats on Mana and on Tutoring to do such incredibly stupid things that I wouldn't be surprised if I could win a few games with DRACO at a Vintage tournament, just because removal or no, Tinker gets my Draco out before you can do carp about it and Lightning Greaves and Animate Dead let me use it as a big honking Ball Lightning if I so choose.

This would be a TERRIBLY weak application of Tinker, but it would totally work against a massive number of decks, because Tinker is dumb.

12383: Tinker.author: Aquillion
12383: Tinker.text_parsed:
Re: Some people suggesting ways to make it balanced.

The amusing thing is that they already printed a balanced version of this -- years before this card was printed. Transmute Artifact is still overwhelmingly powerful, but not game-breaking. (It didn't get as much attention, because there were fewer artifacts when it was current, and it never got reprinted after Antiquities.)

Anyway, this card is even more broken than it seems at first glance. Usually, cost-cheating cards are balanced by the fact that you have to have an expensive card in your hand at the same time to use them; if you draw either one alone, they're useless (or less useful.) Combining tutoring and cost-cheating in one card is almost always going to be gamebreaking. See also Stoneforge Mystic, which made the same mistake.

12384: Slow Motion.author: GrimjawxRULES
12384: Slow Motion.text_parsed:
I understand the concept - trap a unit in a pocket of slowed time and make the controller spend mana on getting it out of there (thanks for the explanation Kivati) - but I think it was executed in the wrong way. This would have felt right if it made use of the phase mechanic - something along the lines of "Enchanted creature has Phasing. Whenever enchanted creature phases in, it's controller may pay . If he/she doesn't, enchanted creature phases out."

Anyway, as it is, this card is powerful. It kills your opponents creatures or slows them down a lot, and the return mechanic means that regular disenchants & naturilizes just won't do. Fits control decks nicely, and should definitely see some play in the casual environment.
Is it too strong? I doubt it, since it was printed in the same set as Rancor, and it was common too (but then again, Urza's block was full of overpowered stuff).

12387: Anthroplasm.author: Forgeling
12387: Anthroplasm.text_parsed: can someone explain to me why this creatures ability doesn't kill it?
12387: Anthroplasm.text_posted: can someone explain to me why this creatures ability doesn't kill it?

12387: Anthroplasm.author: Vellaunus
12387: Anthroplasm.text_parsed:
@Forgeling: Rule 704.4 from the comprehensive rule book.

704.4. Unlike triggered abilities, state-based actions pay no attention to what happens during the resolution of a spell or ability.
Example: A player controls a creature with the ability "This creature's power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand" and casts a spell whose effect is "Discard your hand, then draw seven cards." The creature will temporarily have toughness 0 in the middle of the spell's resolution but will be back up to toughness 7 when the spell finishes resolving. Thus the creature will survive when state-based actions are checked. In contrast, an ability that triggers when the player has no cards in hand goes on the stack after the spell resolves, because its trigger event happened during resolution.

12391: Second Chance.author: DacenOctavio
12391: Second Chance.text_parsed:
Sun Titan + Form of the Dragon.

@ Zubzub:

Priority can't be gained during the resolution of a spell. So there's a bit of falsehood to your "as it resolves" plan. However, the stack is fun to abuse, and this card's ability is not something that happens immediately. You do get priority before it resolves to cast a spell or activate an ability, and then your opponents gain priority in turn order. You could target this with a regress or a boomerang, which would resolve before the triggered ability. When the ability resolves, you can't sacrifice Second Chance, but the ability's wording is such that it doesn't matter. You still get to take the extra turn, and that's where you're right.

12391: Second Chance.author: Ragamander
12391: Second Chance.text_parsed:
What with the 2010 ruling update, this card has become ultra-breakable. Anything that automatically returns a permanent or enchantment to your hand at the beginning of your upkeep gets you infinite turns if you're under 5 life, say, by casting Plunge into Darkness or Lim-Dûl's Vault. Blood Clock/Umbilicus and Vedalken Mastermind are good repeatable bouncers, but there are plenty of other options.

It seems really easy to get that up and running, considering you could play the bouncer, then Plunge or Vault your way to Second Chance. Use something like Phyrexian Unlife and your opponent is probably screwed, unless he or she can reduce you from 6+ to 0 and then hit you for another 10 separately (but still on the same turn). Burn spells, followed by an attack for the game is pretty much their only shot, unless they've got an army of double strikers or something. In which case, it's a good thing there are cards like Wrath of God.

12398: Unearth.author: DarthParallax
12398: Unearth.text_parsed:
They allowed the Graveborn deck to have Entomb, Reanimate, Exhume, and Animate Dead....but they chose Diabolic Servitude over this when it came to the Urza Block card to use.

The creatures they chose were scarily similar to a high-profile tournament winning list, except in singleton, not in 4x.

I think that Graveborn is, forgive me, the 'skeleton' of what is almost the best possible list Reanimator can have. DREDGE can do better, but I would say that buying 4 copies of PDS: Graveborn gives you all the best cards you need for Reanimator.

I get that utility cards being returned can be great C.A. (looking at Bob and Tiago), but I think Tarmogoyf and Skaab Ruinator might be the only 'Bomb' cards I would prefer to Unearth than Reanimate. And tbh, if you are bringing guys back from the dead anytime earlier than Turn 5, without having to sac them at end of turn, then you are doing something broken, are already getting superb value, and should probably be courteous enough to end the game as quickly as possible.

The card is great. Just. Well, there are even greater ones that do the same thing. Reanimate, Animate Dead, and Exhume: between these 3, I don't see a situation where I wouldn't be happier holding them instead of Unearth.

The fact that a 4.6+ star card like Unearth can be arguably outclassed by so many cards just proves how broken messing with the graveyard is, lol.

12398: Unearth.author: Krysto
12398: Unearth.text_parsed:
What most people tend to ignore is that the vast majority of a vintage zombie deck is 3-drops.
Here's an idea of what this gets you:
Geralf's Messenger
Undead Gladiator
Phyrexian Crusader
Zombie Master
Lord of the Undead
Death Baron
Bone Dancer
Cemetery Reaper

And much more if you break out of zombie tribal.

That's the early game. Late game, it's still a 1-drop but can also be cycled for something more useful.

12398: Unearth.author: blurrymadness
12398: Unearth.text_parsed:
Viridian Emissary
Yavimaya Elder
Eternal Witness (funny, because you get this card back when she hits if you want.)

That's a lot of incentive to run this card in B/G, especially since two of those can fetch the black you need for this. This is a "chump in a bottle", and sometimes also puts out monstrosities. Cycling is your worst case scenario!

They all work together as well, ramping/guaranteeing land drops, recurring card advantage. Beauty!

12403: Treacherous Link.author: Artscrafter
12403: Treacherous Link.text_parsed:
This and Pariah do NOT cause either an infinite damage combo or a game-ending infinite loop. Each effect is used once and they would thus cancel each other out. See also the following rule:
614.5. A replacement effect doesn't invoke itself repeatedly and gets only one opportunity for each event.

So if you or the creature were to take damage, whichever replacement effect is currently relevant does its thing, then the other one switches it back. Both replacement effects are used up and the recipient of the damage is the same as it would have been without either of them being there.

On topic for this card: This could go very well on a weak enemy creature that doesn't have a tap ability in combination with Lust for War while you hold a big creature back to block with, such as Rage Nimbus.

12408: No Mercy.author: SpyCrab
12408: No Mercy.text_parsed:
@Sironos:

This is an urza's legacy card, so the story for this card is on the Urza book (Forgot the name of the book but i read it a few years ago).
Urza was an inventor, he and his brother discovered at youth ancient ruins with 2 gems inside. Each one of the took one, his brother though envyed him and wanted to possess his gemstone, which led to a battle that took years and drawn kingdoms into ruins. In the end, urza kills his brother Misha but belives he was corrupted by some force - Phyrexia.
After becoming a planeswalker Urza is obcessed with destroying Phyrexia, after hundreds of years he finds it and attempts to exterminate every single phyrexian. Still, he fails and phyrexia had just discovered his existance.
That is where the card "No Mercy" enters, the one who atacked phyrexia would pay with his blood and the blood of all that would stand by him. The background is the Tolarian Academy (you can see the card), it was a castre that Urza built to train mages into helping him in his cause for the destruction of phyrexia, still, those sweet phyrexians that were watching carefully and infiltrating their ranks as years passed (As you can see the flavor text is a quote from a sleeper agent) had already prepared an offencive. Phyxerian troops end up charging aganish the academy and destroying it. Thats the point of No Mercy.

"We had years to prepare, While they had mere minutes"

12408: No Mercy.author: tavaritz
12408: No Mercy.text_parsed:
@SirMalkin: They are both triggered effects so if you controll both you decide in which order you put them on the stack. If you put No Mercy's first, Dissipation Field's resolves first sending the creature to owners hand and No Mercy's effect is countered with no target and vice verse.

If No Mercy and Dissipation Field are controlled by different players then the active player puts their triggered effects on the stack first and then the non-active player puts theirs.

12408: No Mercy.author: Nagoragama
12408: No Mercy.text_parsed: The actual specific moment in the story this refers to is when Kerrick, a Phyrexian sleeper agent (Phyrexian in human flesh sent to spy on and undermine humanity), had become trapped in a bubble of "fast time" on Tolaria.  Urza and his Academy had conducted experiments attempting to discover how to travel through time to stop the Phyrexians from ever coming about.  However, the experiments went out of control (partially caused by Kerrick himself) and caused a disaster on Tolaria, destroying a large part of it and creating areas of erratic time distortions.  Some were areas of slow time where seconds passed for those trapped inside while years passed outside.  People in areas of fast time, such as the one Kerrick was trapped in, would experience years, while seconds passed in the normal time areas.  Thus Kerrick had a huge amount of time to prepare his attack on the Academy, while the Academy, still reeling from the disaster, had minutes to prepare for his counter attack.
12408: No Mercy.text_posted: The actual specific moment in the story this refers to is when Kerrick, a Phyrexian sleeper agent (Phyrexian in human flesh sent to spy on and undermine humanity), had become trapped in a bubble of "fast time" on Tolaria.  Urza and his Academy had conducted experiments attempting to discover how to travel through time to stop the Phyrexians from ever coming about.  However, the experiments went out of control (partially caused by Kerrick himself) and caused a disaster on Tolaria, destroying a large part of it and creating areas of erratic time distortions.  Some were areas of slow time where seconds passed for those trapped inside while years passed outside.  People in areas of fast time, such as the one Kerrick was trapped in, would experience years, while seconds passed in the normal time areas.  Thus Kerrick had a huge amount of time to prepare his attack on the Academy, while the Academy, still reeling from the disaster, had minutes to prepare for his counter attack.

12411: Defender of Chaos.author: Equinox523
12411: Defender of Chaos.text_parsed: Forms a mirrored pair with Defender of Law, from the same set. Best used to take out white attackers, or as a surprise attacker on your own turn, when flashed into play at the end of your opponent's turn. As a red player, your opponent is likely to assume you have burn in your hand, and will try to play around it - flash creatures like this one allow you to keep dropping creatures onto the board while still keeping mana open during your opponent's turn to either bluff or hold those extra burn spells.

12414: About Face.author: Lateralis0ne
12414: About Face.text_parsed:
I saw a friend use this with Daru Spiritualist and Lightning Greaves. It takes some fancy mana producing, but he was able to get out two Spiritualists and the equipment, bouncing it off the two Spiritualists, giving each +0/+however-much-he-wants, then using this card to switch that power and toughness, and then re-equipping the Greaves to one and attacking for ungodly amounts of damage.

Different, but highly efficient, surprisingly. It was a very good deck, and he was known for making some of the more wacky decks, like Oath of Druids/Serra Avatar, Sneak Attack, Hulk Flash, etc., each with his own personal twist.

12428: Simian Grunts.author: Tiggurix
12428: Simian Grunts.text_parsed: In taxonomy, a creature never stops being what its ancestors were. So, if we take the word "monkey" to mean "creatures of the order Simiiformes (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simiiformes)", then great apes, including humans, can be called "monkeys" (as well as reptiles, fish, etc).

12432: Crop Rotation.author: Salient
12432: Crop Rotation.text_parsed:
Legacy superbeast.

Rotating into a Tabernacle makes aggro/ramp decks cry, rotating into a Glacial Chasm usually buys you two turns of damage-free haven protection, rotating into Wasteland or Rishadan Port lets you wreck the opponent's mana base by surprise, rotating into a City of Traitors provides mana acceleration for , rotating into Karakas bounces legendary beefeaters like Emrakul, and rotating into Bojuka Bog exiles the graveyard of that annoying Dredge or Reanimator player.

Oh, and if they destroyed one of those precious lands, rotate into Petrified Field to recover it.

As for what to sacrifice? It's always nice to have Tranquil Thicket and Tranquil Thicket in your graveyard, but sacking a
Flagstones of Trokair nets you an extra basic land, and sacking Dakmor Salvage lets you recover the loss.

5/5. Possibly my favorite card to play.

12432: Crop Rotation.author: RaymondKHessel

One of those cards that probably should have been considered a second time in the logical sway of sobriety rather than the drunken madness that was Urza's Block. (Full Disclosure: Urza's Block is my favorite block, it's where I did the most playing.) But sometimes (or, in the case of Urza's Block, rather often) you need to step back and dispassionately consider a card a mistake.

Crop Rotation:
-IS a common
-IS an instant
-DOES tutor for land, and not just basic land either
-DOES put the land into play untapped

And all it asks in return is one green mana and that you sac a land. No. Just no.

@vantha @Lifegainwithbite

If this card was reprinted today, it would be a common, or an uncommon at most. The reason why Crop Rotation was so good at the time (and still good in some formats) was because in the same block there were some really, really overpowered lands. Nowadays, there are also some really powerful lands, just not as powerful. Although Cavern of Souls is pretty overpowered, I wouldn't use a card and sacrifice a land just to put it onto the battlefield like I would with Tolarian Academy or Gaea's Cradle.

12433: Rancor.author: liir007
12433: Rancor.text_parsed:
Top 5 Enchantment-Aura (enchant creature) cards:
1. (4.880) Rancor +2/+0 trample that returns from the graveyard
2. (4.845) Treachery steal creature, untap your lands
3. (4.729) Armadillo Cloak +2/+2, trample, gain life
4. (4.562) Faith's Fetters pacifism that can control permanents and 4 life bonus
5. (4.417) Pillory of the Sleepless pacifism that drains opponent's life

Rancor is on this list because it is resistant to creature removal. Regular creature enchantments tend to give your opponent a 2 to 1 card advantage when the creature takes the enchantment with it to the grave. Rancor tends to ignore this problem (just recast it) and forces your opponent to be more creative when it comes to dealing with Rancor.
For mana curve purposes, at 1 mana this enchantment is brutally fast. Also, you don't tend to mind losing your early cheap creatures in combat because you will just be able to recast Rancor on a better creature.

12433: Rancor.author: Equinox523
12433: Rancor.text_parsed: There is a reason I have not dismantled the Unearth deck I've used since Urza's block to this day. This deck, stocked with creatures like Phyrexian Ghoul, Multani's Acolyte, Yavimaya Granger, Yavimaya Elder (holy card advantage Batman!) and Bone Shredder, gets a way to force through some extra damage via extra power and trample. Echo creatures die on their own, or sacrificed to Ghouls, and you don't have to be afraid of "wasting" Rancor on your goons to make them better blockers before they die on their own, and you get it back. Even the lowly Bone Shredder, a 1/1, becomes a threat this stapled onto him.

12437: Harmonic Convergence.author: mrchuckmorris
12437: Harmonic Convergence.text_parsed:
Opponent: "I swing with my super-enchanted general, Zur the Enchanter, and stick him with Diplomatic Immunity! He's been given unblockable, indestructible, and +20/+20 by all his enchantments! Take general damage for the lose!!"

You: "Ha, no, Harmonic Convergence. Oh, and I block with Deadly Recluse."

Opponent: *sad look of defeat* "...Pass turn..."

Aside from this being an effective way to get rid of said Diplomatic Immunity for a while without annihilating your own board position, I'm very interested in seeing how well this could be used against yourself in a Theros-based Heroic deck. You'd only need 5 cheap auras to beat down your opponent with Labyrinth Champion alone.

Sure did cost a lot of mana, but I kept having two creatures no matter what happened, and was drawing cards to boot.

12438: Weatherseed Treefolk.author: JosephColona
12438: Weatherseed Treefolk.text_parsed:
Card of the Week #2
Previous card - Deepcavern Imp

I love green. I want to say that, because I just do. It's easily my favourite color. So much fun, in a very straight forward way. And really that's what I love about green: it's straight forward. It does simple things, like beat for five, in very nice fun ways. Frankly I think this card is just good and fun. Beats spot removal, beats board wipes and beats face.

But that's not even the best part of green, the best part of green is that there is always some sort of fun and cool interactions it has, but it is often ignored because of how straightforward the cards look.

While that second point may not be valid with this specific card, as kookster will tell you with that really cool combo he has jury rigged together to kill in a really unpredictable way, I say it still stands with a lot of really cool green cards, and a lot of green in general.

But, where can you make this card work in EDH?

It serves a function in an Asmira deck. 2GGG: beat five once per turn until an opponent decides to let you pump your general. Repeat. Frankly, while it's doable in the ramp heavy green, its too inefficient.

This and other cards like it that either like being in graveyards or refuse to stay in graveyards can find snug little homes in a card advantage focused Child of Alara deck. Frankly, that just sounds kind of dumb. Board wipe. Oh that doesn't bug me, too bad for you. I'll probably wipe again a few turns from now too by the way. That would definitely get old.

It's a good reusable target for Tuknir Deathlock. Also a good straight forward beater in Stonebrow, Krosan Hero, Borborygmos, or the host of green generals that just give Gaea's Anthem like affects to your creatures or other EDH decks with generals that really just want to beat face. Frankly this isn't bad in any of those decks, and they would all be fun to play. If I had to chose one of those generals I'd go with Stonebrow, it has a good clear focus, a good repeatable method of dealing damage (beat with trample) and the red green lets you to spice in all sorts of fun little hastey tricks, like Anger or Fires of Yavimaya.

Although I think this card is most fun when you really exploit its returning abilities, with things, like I don't know, a sacrifice engine. if you can, in some strange completely unfeasible way, to whip out large swathes of mana, or even infinite mana, in red green black, it combos very nicely with Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper and Kresh the Bloodbraided. I prefer Sek, because spot removal is very high, and very successful in my play group, so having a cool army of 3/1 hastey's is pretty nifty.

Alright, let's pull off this cool little infinite army combo.
First, you need Weatherseed Treefolk out.
Second, you need a sacrifice engine out. Put cool ones, like blasting station (you're just going to play this guy again, so it untaps), Goblin Bombardment (it costs no mana), and Spawning pit (no cost and make even more tokens)
Third, a way to keep playing your sacrifice Weatherseed Treefolk, either something simple and amazing, like the aforementioned deathrender (which is a good way to go as it's just one more card), or some fun infinite mana combo. A google search comes up with some cool ones in red green black. Seriously do it, there are some cool ones.
Four, fill the rest of the deck with land and tutors, so you can alsways get your combo started, and find all the pieces.
Five, play it, and tell cool stories about attacking all four remaining players in the pod of your local EDH league with infinite 3/1 haster's. Then tell sad stories about how you set it up perfectly but forgot someone had a disk out and wiped all you cool dudes, and get teamed on by everyone else and lost.

Bye.

12440: Multani, Maro-Sorcerer.author: liir007
12440: Multani, Maro-Sorcerer.text_parsed: Maro (Also MaRo) is the nickname for longtime Magic: The Gathering card designer Mark Rosewater. The truncated version of his name is both a card and a common shorthand around the Magic playing community. "Maro" cards (of which there are eight as of Time Spiral) reference the number of cards in players' hands and grow more powerful the more there are. From Wikipedia
12440: Multani, Maro-Sorcerer.text_posted: [i][b]Maro[/b] (Also MaRo) is the nickname for longtime Magic: The Gathering card designer Mark Rosewater. The truncated version of his name is both a card and a common shorthand around the Magic playing community. "Maro" cards (of which there are eight as of Time Spiral) reference the number of cards in players' hands and grow more powerful the more there are.[/i]     From Wikipedia

12442: Defense of the Heart.author: Fictionarious
12442: Defense of the Heart.text_parsed:
A perfect example of why at any given time you ought to have some enchantment/artifact or creature removal in your hand. For all that this card is broken, it's no where near as broken as an isochron scepter imprinted with anything. For that matter, it would be easy to wait for your opponent to play this, then just wear away ASAP and think no more of it.
I run two of these in my green deck (my local metagame includes pretty much anything that isn't unglued or unhinged) and it's not bad at all, but like I said, easy to respond to.
And when Rhox and Spearbreaker Behemoth are staring you in the face for letting it go off, you learn to respond to it pretty quickly.

For all that this card is broken, it's no where near as broken as an isochron scepter imprinted with anything.  For that matter, it would be easy to wait for your opponent to play this, then just [autocard]wear away[/autocard] ASAP and think no more of it.
I run two of these in my green deck (my local metagame includes pretty much anything that isn't unglued or unhinged) and it's not bad at all, but like I said, easy to respond to.
And when [autocard]Rhox[/autocard] and [autocard]Spearbreaker Behemoth[/autocard] are staring you in the face for letting it go off, you learn to respond to it pretty quickly.

12442: Defense of the Heart.author: ClowWizardEriol
12442: Defense of the Heart.text_parsed:
The card is powerful but not broken. In the current Vintage/Legacy environment, there are quite a few creatureless decks, so this card would never trigger.

It's more powerful in casual games, because there are usually more creatures. This card is also pretty useful in multiplayer, as someone is likely to have a creature-heavy deck.

12458: Deranged Hermit.author: Salient
12458: Deranged Hermit.text_parsed:
This is a bittersweet bombshell of awesomeness -- Mark Rosewater apparently got in deep trouble for this one, because GAAAASP it saw tournament play, and we can't possibly abide by silly cards getting mainstream competitive attention, now can we? It would give development the vapors.

This is why we can't have nice Squirrel things. :(

...If you feel similarly disappointed with Wizards' decision that we can't have nice Squirrel things, or silly-yet-viable cards more generally, it couldn't hurt to say so in comments...

12490: Multani's Presence.author: MacBizzle
12490: Multani's Presence.text_parsed:
Brain Gorgers, Dash Hopes and Temporal Extortion are a little more playable now. Oh, you don't want my 4/2 for 1B coming out? Okay, sacrifice a creature and I draw a card. Oh, you don't want my black/green deck to have a counterspell? Pay 5 life and let me draw a card. You don't want my black/green deck to get a cheaper Time Warp? Pay half of your life and let me draw a card. And don't even get me started on the mana cost of this card.

Another way to abuse it would be in an enchantment deck with Presence of the Master. Funny that they're both Urza's, are enchantments, both are the presence of some important figure and both work with each other. If you stack three of these, Telepathy simply becomes an Ancestral Recall.

12490: Multani's Presence.author: Salient
12490: Multani's Presence.text_parsed:
I play this in a deck with Chalice of the Void, Glimpse of Nature, twenty-four zero casting cost creatures, and a Grapeshot. :)

It's nowhere near as reliable or powerful as the other Storm combo decks in Legacy, but it's a lot more fun to play. It's glorious to see people scrunch their eyebrows when I play Chalice for zero--what, am I worried about Engineered Explosives or something?--and then go wide-eyed as I drop Presence, let it counter sixteen of my own spells, play a Glimpse or second Presence, and generate a deck's worth of cantrip Storm fodder by auto-countering my own crappy 0cc spells. The Chalice-Presence combo even counters Lotus Petal, Mox Diamond/Opal, Pact of Negation, Engineered Explosives, and any other Chalices I draw, which means I can draw more cards off Presence+Chalice than I can from Glimpse.

Seriously, give it a try, if only for the LOLZ.

12490: Multani's Presence.author: blurrymadness
12490: Multani's Presence.text_parsed:
Holy crap, this + blood funnel, + 2 mana non-creature artifacts = B/G unlimited draw. Have a "win now" card? Do that straight into Tendrils.

Oh, and Tendrils will cost you 2 mana.

And you can do this turn 3 without expensive cards or turn 2 with a bunch of things like exploration, spirit guides or some such.

T2 storm wins for <$20 sounds really tempting to try; probabl $120 with good land support, sideboard, and some shinanigans to get around problem cards.

Mind you, green is the Anti-blue and is the anti-permanent; nothing can survive green with proper cards, meaning main or side you could have an answer to any of your answers.

12503: Damping Engine.author: jonrds
12503: Damping Engine.text_parsed:
@aPimpNamedEmrakul

Common misunderstanding. "Any other" can either mean "each other" or "any one other". The oracle text cleared this up, so it definitely does only affect one person in multiplayer.

As for how to use this card, I would suggest focusing on instants and sorceries, with as few permanents as possible (preferably planeswalkers). Avoid anything that repeatedly gives permanents (such as forbidden orchard). The hunted cycle is acceptable, but if you are playing the right deck you shouldnt need to give your opponent permanents for this to favor you.

12504: Beast of Burden.author: Nevermoore
12504: Beast of Burden.text_parsed: okay, here it goes: Beast of Burden gets "bigger" every time a creature comes into play because of the concept behind the Beast of Burden. Karn was ultimately used to extinguish Phyrexia via Urza's Legacy Weapon . The Phyrexians numbered in the billions, I could only imagine, so Karn was 'made' equally ( if not slightly more) powerful than the forces he was up against. He had the responsibility (or burden in this case) to have the destiny of potentially being destroyed for the sake of saving countless worlds from the Phyrexians. This such being (depicted on this print) is a similar construct created to carry the weatherlight as it was growing, ergo the golem's size/power had to equally match the necessity of protecting such an important collection. The Beast of Burden, i believe, is being mistaken for a metaphorical construct that implies offence, not defense as it is intened.
12504: Beast of Burden.text_posted: okay, here it goes: Beast of Burden gets "bigger" every time a creature comes into play because of the concept behind the Beast of Burden. The Phyrexians numbered in the billions, I could only imagine, so Karn was 'made' equally ( if not slightly more) powerful than the forces he was up against. He had the responsibility (or burden in this case) to have the destiny of potentially being destroyed for the sake of saving countless worlds from the Phyrexians. This such being (depicted on this print) is a similar construct created to carry the [autocard]weatherlight[/autocard] as it was growing, ergo the golem's size/power had to equally match the necessity of protecting such an important collection. 12580: Palinchron.author: blurrymadness
12580: Palinchron.text_parsed:
@stormkeeper
That doesn't work:
5 islands, tap 1 for high tide
4 islands tap for 8 mana, pay for this guy, have 1 floating
untap the islands, tap 2 to return him to your hand
tap 3 islands and use the 1 mana floating to put him back into play
and now you only have 10 mana; less than the first time you played him.

It can't go infinite because it requires 11 mana to do the combo (4 to return, 7 to put him back into play) but you only generate 10. You need two high tides, another island, or some other piece that reduces costs or something to make that work.

12633: Urza's Blueprints.author: majinara
12633: Urza's Blueprints.text_parsed:
How can you say Jayemdae Tome is better? Here the average cost per card drawn by Tome and Blueprints:
Draw 1: Tome: 8, Blueprints: 6
Draw 2: Tome: 6, Blueprints: 6 or 3 (if you activate it in response to the upkeep cost)
Draw 3: 5.3, Blueprints: 4
Draw 4: 5, Blueprints: 3
Draw 5: 4,8 Blueprints: 2,4

So, the tome can be used on turn 5, which is one turn earlier than the blueprints. However, the tome is much more expensive to draw cards with. Also, if you play the tome without having the mana to instantly activate it, you give your opponent the chance to kill it before you can get any value of it. The blueprints however can be tapped the turn you play them, in response to any removal.

I'd play the blueprints always over the tome.

Draw 5: 4,8 Blueprints: 2,4

So, the tome can be used on turn 5, which is one turn earlier than the blueprints. However, the tome is much more expensive to draw cards with. Also, if you play the tome without having the mana to instantly activate it, you give your opponent the chance to kill it before you can get any value of it. The blueprints however can be tapped the turn you play them, in response to any removal.

I'd play the blueprints always over the tome.

12633: Urza's Blueprints.author: Lyoncet
12633: Urza's Blueprints.text_parsed:
In my never-ending quest to gain sustained card advantage in artifact decks, having discounted Howling Mine tapping shenanigans and Trigon of Thought bouncing, I landed on good old Urza's Blueprints. Actually, I'm pleasantly surprised. With the addition of Grand Architect to the scene, by turn 4-5 you're usually going to be heavy on (colorless) mana and low on cards. When every one of your Trinket Mages, Etherium Sculptors, and Riddlesmiths can tap to produce 2 and mana accelerators like Everflowing Chalice and Grim Monolith abound, playing this by turn 3-4 becomes trivial, as does paying the echo cost. And after that, you're pretty much set; grab some Voltaic Keys and go to town. No muss, no fuss, no paying or bouncing to put counters back on, no tapping it down with Vedalken Certarch to keep ahead, just straight up, hard card advantage. Also, this has the advantage over Vedalken Archmage of not murdering you if you have more than one out. It gives you complete control over your draws, whereas too many Archmages will deck you before you know what happened.

The other standbys for draw in artifact decks, Thoughtcast and Thirst for Knowledge, still have their place. But with how much artifact acceleration blue has gotten recently, this is starting to become more and more appealing. I certainly still see more aggro-based decks preferring the instants, though.

And run this with Karn, Silver Golem or March of the Machines so your opponent can experience the sheer terror of a 6/6 piece of paper crushing their armies!

12633: Urza's Blueprints.author: endersblade
12633: Urza's Blueprints.text_parsed:
Mike-C, I fail to see how Venser (I'm assuming you're talking about the planeswalker) can do anything useful with this, other than making you pay the echo cost every turn. You play this, and can only use Venser's ability any time you can play a sorcery. So even if you bounced it, it would come back in, and on your next turn, you'd STILL have to pay the upkeep cost. Unless you plan on playing it, tapping, bouncing, then tapping again, then sac'ing next turn, which to me seems like a huge waste of mana.

Thick-skinned Goblin or Eon Hub would be great for cards like this. I've actually made a deck that involves lots of cheap cards with echo, and not having to pay their costs. Definitely not a competitive deck, but it's fun none the less.

I also use this card mostly in EDH. over 2 turns isn't all that bad in this format, especially in the right deck. Even without Tolarian Academy in the format, it's not unusual for a good deck to have 8+ mana on turn 3 or 4.

You know the effect itself is interesting, but it doesn't belong on a card with that cost.

This card would have been nice if it only affected your creatures. I mean it requires 10 mana to keep that buff permanently, or six mana at once to buff your creatures for a round.
Compare it to Glorious Anthem for example, i don't see where this should have been broken.

I guess the idea behind that was that mainly the players suffer more damage through combat, and it can be useful with creatures that have abilities that get stronger with bigger power, but i don't want to pay that much for that, especially when it backlashes when my opponents attack.

And if we get a cheaper 'general buff' one day, i might fool around a bit with cards like Meekstone or Intrepid Hero.

12647: Ticking Gnomes.author: Technetium
12647: Ticking Gnomes.text_parsed:
I found this card fairly underused during the time it was Standard legal. I had 4 in my blue control deck, which went 3-0 at a Regionals before I made a stupid mistake, and this card was a frequent surprise for my opponents and frequently essential to my victory. There were two main reasons this card worked wonders for me.

1. Mother of Runes
2. Skirge Familiar

These cards were integral to two of the strongest decks at the time, and Ticking Gnomes could take care of them using colorless damage (especially important regarding the mother of runes). In the event it stays out as a creature, it's reliable damage as well.

12668: Pyromancy.author: Equinox523
12668: Pyromancy.text_parsed:
This appears to be a take on Stormbind, an oldschool card that converted unused cards in your hand into Shocks. The difference, other than the costs involved, is that you can get 0 damage when you discard a land. As with most random discard, it is best utilized when you control it - for example, playing this in an eldrazi deck, and using it when you have a ton of huge monsters and no lands in your hand.

Also, RIP Quinton Hoover, one of the all-time iconic Magic artists. While this may not be one of his most remembered cards, the art is pretty darn cool still.

12672: Repopulate.author: Ligerman30
12672: Repopulate.text_parsed: In EDH where most people don't run sideboards, it's generally extremely important to be able to hose graveyards in the maindeck due to how powerful and abusive graveyard recursion strategies are.  Now, the biggest problem with graveyard hosers, is that they are super on or super off.  With this it's all upside, either a) this card is good, you cast it and blow them out b)this card does nothing, you cycle it and go deeper in your deck and are a turn closer to drawing into the cards you need.  Yeah, this only hits creatures but, it's instant speed and never a dead card.  It also has the added bonus of being able to "gain life" against a dedicated mill deck.

12822: Opportunity.author: majinara
12822: Opportunity.text_parsed:
Great card. Six mana is a lot, but worth it. Apart from the mana cost, it has no drawback. Four mana is quite a large number of cards, and instant speed makes sure that you can play it at the end of your opponents turn.

That it doesn't just say "you draw" but "target player" has both advantages and disadvantages. The disadvantage is that you can't play it if you got shroud and that it can be redirected. The advantage is that you can use it in team games on your teammates, in free for all games for multiplayer politics, in rare cases as a final mill card, or to have an opponent be forsced to discard down to 7 or whatnot.

All in all a very nice card.

12822: Opportunity.author: Equinox523
12822: Opportunity.text_parsed:
One little 6-letter word makes all the difference: Instant. At a time when blue had access to "free" spells like Cloud of Faeries, Rewind and Palinchron, this was icing on the cake, allowing you to hold your mana open on your turn and wait for something to counter. If your opponent didn't cast anything to counter, then you'd draw 4 with this, and then on at the start of your turn. This led to all kinds of bluffing games, allowing you to stock up your hand when you were low without tapping out and risking something potentially fatal like Sneak Attack.

Out of its degenerate environment, this is still a fine card. It is still an excellent surprise, and can help you dig deep if you're looking for a lategame Hail Mary. It goes without saying that this is pretty nice with things like Soramaro, First to Dream or Niv-Mizzet, The Firemind.

If your opponent didn't cast anything to counter, then you'd draw 4 with this, and then on at the start of your turn.  This led to all kinds of bluffing games, allowing you to stock up your hand when you were low without tapping out and risking something potentially fatal like [autocard]Sneak Attack[/autocard].

Then, right before it comes around to your turn again, use [autocard]Auratog[/autocard] or [autocard]Faith Healer[/autocard] to sacrifice either your Aura Flux or your Enchanted Evening, whichever is less important to your deck.  Now you've just hit them with a one-sided [autocard]Razia's Purification[/autocard].  Not too bad.

12955: Karmic Guide.author: Ragamander
12955: Karmic Guide.text_parsed:
I don't see why you need more than two Karmic Guides for the infinite mana combo. You play the first, sacrifice it to Ashnod's Altar, play the second, target the first with its ability, and, while its ability is still on the stack, sacrifice the second one to Ashnod's Altar. It'll be in the graveyard to be the target of the first Karmic Guide.

Also, Gemstone Array makes a far better filter than Farrelite Priest, as does Skyshroud Elf if you also run green. Furthermore, you can run Carnage Altar to draw your deck (i.e. draw your win method).

Ashnod's Altar even helps generate the mana necessary to play the two Karmic Guides. Ideally, I'm thinking any two creatures by turn two (Raise the Alarm seems good), Ashnod's Altar on turn three, then two Karmic Guides and Carnage Altar to draw and play your win method on turn four. Dawnglow Infusion and Test of Endurance perhaps? Tons of creatures and just hope for the best? Seems tough in mono-white. Personally, I'd probably splash red or a filter and go for Goblin Bombardment or Pandemonium, but there are probably more amusing combos to use when you've got your whole deck in your hand.

13001: Goblin Welder.author: GrimjawxRULES
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
The flavor text never ceases to amuse me :)

Just felt like pointing out that the errata text can be misunderstood due to lack of clarification on the whereabouts of the artifacts.
"Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact card to the battlefield."
^Of course, you sacrifice the artifact that is currently on the battlefield and then returns the artifact that was in your graveyard as you chose targets for this ability, but the way it's written could lead some people to think that you'd just sacrifice the artifact on the battlefield and then return it to the battlefield again.
13001: Goblin Welder.text_posted:
The flavor text never ceases to amuse me :)

Just felt like pointing out that the errata text can be misunderstood due to lack of clarification on the whereabouts of the artifacts.
"[i]Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices [u]the artifact[/u] and returns [u]the artifact[/u] card to the battlefield.[/i]"
^Of course, you sacrifice the artifact that is currently on the battlefield and then returns the artifact that was in your graveyard as you chose targets for this ability, but the way it's written could lead some people to think that you'd just sacrifice the artifact on the battlefield and then return it to the battlefield again.

13001: Goblin Welder.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
Haha, I love it! This is almost certainly the one Goblin Artificer that nobody would argue is marginal.

I have loved and collected goblins for a long time... when Urza's Legacy was still relatively fresh and new, I remember seeing so many of these in a vendor's dollar rare box. I looked at the card, thought "Meh... but it's a goblin"... and bought one.

I still kick myself for that to this day.

@Grimjaw: Agreed re: flavour text, 100%. The temptation to ask an opponent if they have any ashtrays in their graveyard is just too strong to pass up.

13001: Goblin Welder.author: djbon2112
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
@GrimjawxRULES: You missed a word:

"Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact card to the battlefield."

I did too on first pass, and thought the exact same thing. But if you notice it refers to "artifact" for the one on the battlefield (because it's a artifact permanent), and "artifact card" for the one in the graveyard (because it's a card in the graveyard of type "artifact"), it makes sense.

And I agree the flavour text rocks. I lol'd when I first read this back in the day.
13001: Goblin Welder.text_posted:

I did too on first pass, and thought the exact same thing. But if you notice it refers to "artifact" for the one on the battlefield (because it's a artifact permanent), and "artifact card" for the one in the graveyard (because it's a card in the graveyard of type "artifact"), it makes sense.

13001: Goblin Welder.author: Mode
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
According to the flavor (text), it would make more sense if it read

Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard with a converted mana cost equal or less to the converted mana cost of the artifact. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact card to the battlefield.

As it is, the flavor text might as well read:
"I wrecked your ashtray, boss. But look I made you a metal guy."

(Since he apparently is able to do just that, i'm pretty sure he got a promotion after that incident.)
I mean, damn. If he's got the scrap metal, he can turn a Darksteel Relic into a whole Darksteel Forge.
Now tell me that's not impressive!

13001: Goblin Welder.author: Aquillion
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
Fun with Modular creatures. Also, note that it can be used to fizzle anything that targets one of your artifacts.

But of course its real power is serving as a reusable one-mana animate dead for artifacts.

Also: I'm not quite sure where this belongs on the color wheel, but red is the last place I would have put it. Blue would be a lot more logical. Sure, you can use it on your opponent's artifacts, but most of the time you won't be putting it in your deck for that (if only because you can't rely on your opponent having two artifacts that you want to swap, one in their graveyard.) That's more a happy side-benefit to its real power.

13001: Goblin Welder.author: Arachnos
13001: Goblin Welder.text_parsed:
Pros compared to Tinker:

-Only costs {R} to come out, subsequent activations FREE
-Reusable
-Destroyed artifacts can be fished back out
-Hits opponents

Cons compared to Tinker:

-Does not search library, card needs to be in graveyard. Comboes with Entomb, Buried Alive, but that requires splashing black
-Summoning sickness
-1/1 body dies to absolutely everything and anything

13810: Ghitu War Cry.author: asmallcat
13810: Ghitu War Cry.text_parsed:
Global firebreathing? Yes please. Still, only terribly useful if your deck has a lot of expendable creatures. If it rides one to victory, you're better off with firebreathing.

I played a deck with one Mountain, every single 0-cost creature I could find, and this card.

5703: Rank and File.author: zombietomb

5704: Mother of Runes.author: Dischade
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed:
Oh yes. This card is a 4 of in every cleric deck period. This card sets the tone for the game as your enemies stare blankly at your side of the board and pray for two kill spells to stop this from winning you the game. This is evasion, protection for your creatures, a blocking MACHINE, and a cleric for the other various cleric related abilities. This is easily one of the best one drops in the game.

If you play with a casual group of friends often, the only way they will let you play this is in a straight cleric tribal deck, and if you play multiplayer with the same people, be ready to take some serious hate, then laugh as you win the game anyway.

This should have been legendary, because having two or more out is exponentially worse than just one.

5/5

5704: Mother of Runes.author: JaxsonBateman
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed:
Such a fantastic card in a wide variety of Wx decks. I haven't had much experience with her, but I put her into a monowhite lifegain deck I've been working on, and she's a superstar. Early on she blocks most creatures outright due to lack of trample, so she keeps you alive while you get bigger creatures out (or draw into removal). Beyond that, she basically says "targetted spot removal now equates to card disadvantage".

She also goes a fair way towards making your creatures unblockable (take that blue!), so even in a weenie deck she could find a home. All in all, a great card, and one of the best 1 drops there is.

5704: Mother of Runes.author: Nagoragama
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed: This card seems pretty good at first glance.  However, you don't truly understand the sheer power of this card until you play it or play against it.  It can make your creatures unblockable.  It counters removal.  Its mere presence on the field totally changes the way your opponent plays, forcing him to consider what you're going to do next with it with every move he makes.  One of the best 1 drops in the game.

5704: Mother of Runes.author: Ligerman30
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed: I'd say this is, straight up, the best white 1 drop of all time. But, I'd only be mostly right, in EDH Serra Ascendant is a 1 mana 6/6 flying lifelinker and is almost auto-scoop in 1v1. Overall as a card in all formats, this is not only the best one drop in white, it's among the greatest 1 drops of all time. If your opponent ever untaps with this, it will mess up combat counter removal spells and is stupidly good in multiples all with no further mana investment. Imagine how much worse it would be if you had to pay & tap to activate, it would be a lot worse but it would still be very good. That is how amazing this card is.

5704: Mother of Runes.author: LlanowarEmissary
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed:
It doesn't get much better than this in terms of one-drops. Mom's a pretty frustrating card to face down, especially when she comes out turn one. If you don't find a way to deal with her - which often involves 2 or more cards - you'll have trouble dealing with every other creature your opponent drops. I think I hate playing against this card more than I like playing it, but either way it's incredibly efficient and one of the rare one-drops that's valuable whether you play her in the beginning, middle, or end of the game.

5/5, though I paused for a minute before rating because she just looks so darn unassuming and smug, quietly sipping her tea while you tear your hair out.

5704: Mother of Runes.author: blurrymadness
5704: Mother of Runes.text_parsed:
She is a pillar to many a legacy deck. She smuggly dominates removal strategies, especially if supported by token producers. She's a 1-drop that blocks Goyf and KotR; even titans; and has no issues doing so.

Her damage prevention means that you can block something holding a Jitte and give up no counters to it.

She causes unblockability of a color allowing one to get final bits of damage through. She's a powerhouse that only gets better with time. Just like the "cycle" of insane 2-drops, she's in the cycle of insane 1-drops that holds legacy together.



(Consider Devoted Caretaker when it comes to a deck that utilizes important enchantments/artifacts)

8814: Opal Avenger.author: Arachobia
8814: Opal Avenger.text_parsed:
Random Card Comment

I admit, the 'sleeper' enchantments were one of my favorite cycles. Possibly because when I first started magic, the Urza's cycle was myvery first booster pack purchase. But I think I like the flavor of enchanted statues that 'awaken' when they are threatened. This is an especialyl flavorful card for that. As your enemy comes cloer (your life drops) the statues that adorn you fortress suddenly begin to come to life to repel the intruders and fight back. To top it off, the original type of this card was even 'guardian'. It somewhat puzzles me that unlike Ivory Guardians this was errated to just 'soldier' not 'giant soldier'.

Anyway, it may not be the easiest slepper to awaken, but it's fairly cheap and I love the flavor, plus it has nostalgia for me because I enjoyed the cycle and still like to make decks around the mechanic for casual paly.

8814: Opal Avenger.author: syrazemyla
8814: Opal Avenger.text_parsed:
Would playing Enchanted Evening and this result in a draw?

When you have 10 or less life, it would turn into a Creature. But it would turn into an Enchantment Creature, and thus try to turn into a creature again, and again, until one of them were destroyed or you went to 11 or more health.
8814: Opal Avenger.text_posted:
Would playing [autocard]Enchanted Evening[/autocard] and this result in a draw?

When you have 10 or less life, it would turn into a Creature.  But it would turn into an Enchantment Creature, and thus try to turn into a creature again, and again, until one of them were destroyed or you went to 11 or more health.

8814: Opal Avenger.author: TheWrathofShane
8814: Opal Avenger.text_parsed:
Not so easy condition to fullfill, with only a 3/5 "vanilla" creature as a reward. Consider me not impressed.

@Syrazemyla
Its a state based effect, not triggered ability. Not sure what would happen, but I dont think a state based effect infinite loop could draw the game. Only triggered ability infinite loop would.

8831: Quicksilver Amulet.author: DeathDark
8831: Quicksilver Amulet.text_parsed:
Strictly inferior to Elvish Piper. Piper is legal in standard, and her effect only costs G. In order to play-and-drop with this, you need 8 mana sources. In order to play-and-drop with Piper, you need 5 mana sources, two of them green.

Getting Darksteel Colossus or Progenitus out quick? How about summoning Progenitus on THEIR 3rd turn after they declare attackers? Next turn you bring out Lorthos, the Tidemaker and ANOTHER Piper. The person I did that to forfeited soon after that.

8831: Quicksilver Amulet.author: RafiqTheMiststalker
8831: Quicksilver Amulet.text_parsed:
@DeathDark

It doesn't take 8 mana sources. It takes 4. You cast turn 4, then drop Kozilek and what have you on turn 5. It's not meant to be held on to til the 8th turn -_-

It's also NOT strictly worse. This is colorless, and Elvish Piper can be removed by the rampant creature removal of today. I'm not the type to flame every creature because Swords and Bolt exist, but this not being a creature is a plus. And artifacts have ton of cheat into play cards and colorless acceleration like the Urzatron.

Elvish Piper IS good, and I'd rather use it. But don't be so black and white about cards.
They are both useful cards.

8831: Quicksilver Amulet.author: majinara
8831: Quicksilver Amulet.text_parsed:
@ DeathDark: Inferior to Elvish Piper? You got to be kidding me. This amulet is far better than the piper. It doesn't neet green mana, it's no 1 toughness dork that dies when you pat him on the shoulder, and it can be used the turn it comes into play, while the piper has to sit around for a full turn. Sitting around for full turn is a huge disadvantage, since you give your opponent the possibility to react with sorcery speed removal, to draw another card that might be the removal one, and to untap, so your opponent has the mana available to play any removal.
This card ain't the best card ever, but it's waaaaaaaaaaaay better than the piper.

8832: Angel's Trumpet.author: a7141988
8832: Angel's Trumpet.text_parsed: Have you guys considered Darien, King of Kjeldor EDH? I play this and your options are: 1) Trash it, 2) Attack me and I get soldiers, 3) Don't attack, and you take damage and your creatures are tapped down, or 4) Get rid of Darien by shuffling it into my library or gaining control of it. For the Darien deck, since my opponent's creatures are now tapped down, I can alpha strike without worrying about blockers and, due to the vigilance this card provides, I will have blockers in case they decide to attack me. If I choose not to attack and I have Soul Warden-type effect on the field, then I'll get a bunch of soldiers, which can serve as skullclamp fodder or beef up dudes with Coat of Arm or what have you.

8832: Angel's Trumpet.author: TheGigiBeast
8832: Angel's Trumpet.text_parsed:
Ok guys, here is my idea for my Phenax EDH:

1) Play this and have a Propaganda on the field and your Phenax.
2) Attack with all of your creatures to avoid damage (good with Mindcrank).
3) Tap all your creatures to mill your opponents because of Phenax effect. A good creature for this combo is, for exemple, Nemesis of Reason.

*4)* Your opponents will have an hard time attacking you because of the Propaganda, they will most likely take damage. Even if you don't have the Propaganda on the field, this combo still works, but you are not protected against your opponents creatures.

8897: Defense Grid.author: Tezz
8897: Defense Grid.text_parsed: so do you pay extra if its not your turn? and do opponents pay extra is their turns?
8897: Defense Grid.text_posted: so do you pay extra if its not your turn? and do opponents pay extra is their turns?

8897: Defense Grid.author: DoctorKenneth
8897: Defense Grid.text_parsed:
Tezz: Yes, you would pay extra for spells if it is not your turn. Your opponents pay extra for spells on your turn, or on their other opponent's turns (in a multiplayer game).

That said, this is a nice anti-counterspell strategy, one of the few without colour commitment. It's a little limited in other areas, as it's simple enough (and not THAT hampering) for foes to confine removal and other instants to their own turns. So, I would recommned sideboard at best- while there's better anti-instant tech, this fits in a wider variety of decks than most.

9699: Fog of Gnats.author: yyukichigai
9699: Fog of Gnats.text_parsed:
Will-o'-the-Wisp will almost always be better than these guys, except in two situations:
1) You need a creature with some offensive power (or a 1/1 in particular, e.g. Pendelhaven)
2) You'd rather pay 50¢ apiece for these versus ~$3 each for the Wisps

That being said, the Gnats are still a phenomenal creature for anybody playing black beyond just a light splashing. The Wisps are literally the best Black creature WotC has ever produced, or in the top 3 at the very least; another creature not quite being equal to that says almost nothing about the card.

Also as a bonus, these guys work with Swarmyard... though that's sort of pointless when you get down to it.

9840: Tethered Skirge.text_parsed: Not much of a drawback really. black doesn't get fliers as much as blue or white. Usually if its targeted it will also die, and you lose one life. Not a big deal, and a 2/2 evasion is a pretty solid body. Its not the best option black has, but its not an awful card.
